title: What do the signs '+', '-' mean in piano notes? - Quora

response.answer_text: “+” indicates the notes higher(sharper) than the normal one and “-” indicates the notes lower(flat) than the normal one like i have a 49 keys piano, so there are 3 full octaves in it in which the middle one goes like A B C D E F G . then the octave on it’s left goes like A- B- C- D- E- F- G-. then the octave on it’s right goes like A+ B+ C+ D+ E+ F+ G+ (these are only for white keys) and the black keys are normal like A# and Ab. hope it helps you

This looks to me like some sort of home-made code for pitch and rhythm notation. Possibly the + means to hold the note for one more value of whatever you are holding it for. So the first three notes (B C# and D) would be played eighth, quarter, quarter (or possibly quarter, half, half). I glean that from most of the groupings adding up to eight (with some errors, that is). Maybe. Without knowing  what the person meant who wrote it, we can only guess. Any idea what the title/composer is?

The + (confusingly called the "double cross", while # is the single one) before a note raises the note by two half steps. The - (above a note) indicates that the note should be sustained at full length, not cut off beforehand. EDIT I see question details have been added, to which my answer does not fit.

In French baroque music the + indicates a tremblement, which is a type of trill. The - is a fairly standard notation called tenuto, and indicates the note be played full value, if not ever so slightly longer. (I had to look up the + on wikipedia, I didn’t know what it meant on other than string and percussion music)
